comments.commentBody: While I appreciate article written, I take offense to the general tone of the piece. Upon closer examination, I found that every reference to potential shady dealings were not directly performed or related to Harmony Schools. Such as the example of visa problems charter schools faced importing unqualified teachers. That not nothing to do with the Harmony Schools. I also noticed that no one directly working for or related to Harmony Schools (teachers, principals, parents, etc.) were interviewed. It makes me wonder what light or angle these people (had they been interviewed) would have contributed to this article. Maybe that's part of the problem.
These are great schools and parents are very happy with their level of education. Just leave them alone and let them do their work !

I do not teach one religion. I do not attempt to sway my students to one religion. I teach Social Studies in a diverse school with diverse ideas and diverse families. I teach students how to make their own decisions and not simply accept what they read as the complete truth (as I wished this writer would have). I have been with Harmony for a while, have experience also in public and private education sectors. The schools of Harmony, and I have visited almost 8, are some of the finest schools for students and communities that lack such arenas for growth. Sure, no system is perfect. And this system is young, at only 10 years old. It has become more opened and more diverse. The article is missing so much. The sources gave her assistance in the writing of this article, yet Harmony is portrayed as mostly a negative force in education. Ask a child, a parent, a teacher for the real story. Ask the child that is working hard and has to drive with her single-working mom 15 miles every day, back and forth, to her Harmony school, then go to work. She does not go to her assigned neighborhood school because it is in terrible shape and has a dangerous environment. Harmony was another option, and a better one for her. Bottom line this is the most ridiculous and incomplete article I have read in a long time from one of my favorite papers.

Charters open up the the education sector to a wild west of cronyism and corruption.  I'm constantly astounded by  the widespread acceptance of a system the public pays for, but whose benefits most are not entitled to enjoy.

This is very disappointing to me, because I have seen NBC ignore or minimally cover my (Olympic) sport during non-Olympic years.  A network that wants the Olympics should be committed as a principle to covering its sports during all 4 years of the cycle, not just during the Olympic year when it's most profitable to them.

A fun, entertaining, high energy production.  It's not Shakespeare but very cute and clever and could be on B'way for a good long time.  Very audience-friendly performances by all, but especially by Miller and Clark.  Terrific lighting, too.
A good show but certainly not memorable nor unique.  Tveit is terrific and Butz successfully steals every scene (as is his intention) but the story is predictable and the music very, very ordinary.
Now this is just gross.  Not so much older people doing the deed as writing and talking about old people doing the deed.

Personally I hate this. It also bugs me that they play loud music between innings at baseball games. Besides the greatness of the game itself, seeing baseball also used to be social where you could catch up with your friends. The obnoxious music makes it hard to do.  At least with TV, you can mute.

DH: Fear is a powerful motivator, but talking off the top of your head is a bad habit. The studies I refer to were not surveys or interviews, nor were they Brodeur's unscientific extrapolations. He committed plenty of the latter, yes. But the laboratory studies he cited examined cellular damage in chicken eggs caused by specific frequencies that caused DNA damage. An analogy would be the common macro-physical event when a high "C" resonates the crystalline structure of glass enough to cause it to shatter. "So is one frequency harmonic harmful, and the other helpful?" Your question is dismissive and meant rhetorically, but yes, that is exactly the point.

If anyone out there is familiar with said lab studies, and has genuine information on the validity of the experiments themselves (and not a lot of unrelated rhetorical issues, please?), it would be great to hear from someone who knows what they are talking about.

The outcry against this news is like those who simply will not take advantage of prevention screening tests offered by health insurances, Medicare, and at health fairs. Yes, it's a challenge to get checked out, and wait for results - no one wants bad news, but a high number in society in the USA simply does not accept reality.

The fish rots from the head down. We cannot ignore what is now so prevalent among our political leaders who balk at accepting their responsiblity to protect Americans, and on and on. Raise taxes to get us through a crisis, Texas not using their "Rainey Day Fund" to keep children educated and hlep their disabled, our extremist House and Senate daring to try and repeal health care coverage for millions, and . . . sigh . . . it never stops.
Just the thought of how may waiting rooms in which I'll now actually be able to sit and wait. Thank you.

Nearly 20 years ago, I used a company-issued Motorola Star Tac for three years on a near daily basis, mostly in the car to get a jump on my work day as I drove to/from work. Being left handed, I always used the phone in my right ear, so that I could use my left hand to drive or take notes. A few years after I stopped using that phone (or any cellphone), I discovered hearing loss in my right ear, and was diagnosed with an acoustic neuroma. In the process of having it removed, I lost all hearing in that ear. My doctors told me that there was "no evidence" that it was caused by the cell phone, but I have always believed that there is a connection. I had never even heard of an acoustic neuroma before this happened.

Since then, I resumed using cellphones, but have always used an earpiece, for the safety, comfort, and better sound that it provides. But lately I have been using a bluetooth - time to go back to a wired earpiece!

From a quick Google scholar search, it seems that Delgado's "Henhouse" project of the 1980s (probably one of those cited by Brodeur) have been confirmed and are still being explored by experiments concerned with specific frequencies of ELF (Extremely Low Frequency) electromagnetic radiation. When the discussion of effects is in terms of how strong the field is, I think it misses this crucial aspect. Here's a 2010 synopsis:

"The effects of extremely low frequency magnetic fields (ELF-MF) on acetylcholinesterase (AChE) activity of synaptosomal membranes were investigated. Sinusoidal fields with 50 Hz frequency and different amplitudes caused AChE activity to decrease about 27% with a threshold of about 0.74 mT. The decrease in enzymatic activity was independent of the time of permanence in the field and was completely reversible. Identical results were obtained with exposure to static MF of the same amplitudes. Moreover, the inhibitory effects on enzymatic activity are spread over frequency windows with different maximal values at 60, 200, 350, and 475 Hz. When synaptosomal membranes were solubilized with Triton, ELF-MF did not affect AChE activity, suggesting the crucial role of the membrane, as well as the lipid linkage of the enzyme, in determining the conditions for inactivation. The results are discussed in order to give an interpretation at molecular level of the macroscopic effects produced by ELF-MF on biological systems, in particular the alterations of embryo development in many organisms due to acetylcholine accumulation." Bioelectromagnetics 31:270–276, 2010. © 2009 Wiley-Liss, Inc.

i think it s wonderful only in that it will bring what makes this world go 'round:JOBS so yeah the casinos are always a good thing in that respect and we should all be ever the more grateful if only for that GOD BLESS! queens.
Children have been learning math this way in Montessori schools for 100 years.

Oh Wow! Cell phone use causes increased glucose metabolism. In other words your brain is functioning when you use a cell phone!!. I should hope so!
Do you realize that glucose metabolism is a human body function that produces oxygen ions (oxidants) as a side effect. The body also produces anti-oxidants to reduce the number, BECAUSE oxidants are ions which are capable of ripping an atom out of a DNA molecule and thus producing a DNA defect which sometimes results in cancer. BINGO! a physical link from cell phones to cancer. Trouble is the cell phone cause is trivial compared to the cause of just plain living. It takes more energy (glucose metabolism) to eat, breathe, walk and talk etc than to use a cell phone, and this is probably trivial compared to the higher levels of radiation from the sun to which we are all exposed. AND without the sunlight we would all die. So the precautionary principle choice becomes stop breathing oxygen or live with the risk of oxident induced cancer.

So we have established that there is a level of risk to cell phones that induces increased communication, and to eating and breathing that produces oxidant ions that allows functioning, and a level of risk to gasoline and fuel that allows increased transportation (& auto accidents) etc. We also have a WHO investigative branch that has resulted in more use of dangerous printers ink and PC display radiation by publishing a study that scared the bejesus out of the unsuspecting ignorant gullible public, by using an absurd grading system ("possible" carcinogen).

What is needed is a much much better WHO grading system, to be able to compare the relative risks/rewards and cost/benefits of various elements compounds and technologies. Right now we have a cancer risk coming from breathing oxygen, that is far more dangerous than the low "possible" cancer risk (if any!)/high reward of a cell phone. Logically we should ban breathing to prevent cancer (ignoring other consequences!) before we tackle the much smaller problem of cell phones. This is implicitly in place by the FCC etc in restricting cell phone radiation to a small fraction of that what is known to cause problems.

Then there is the problem that the publicity of the WHO non-finding has caused more worrying by mothers concerned about their children, which in turn has caused more glucose metabolism and so more cancer than the report was worth in the first place.

In summary, it is my feeling that the crazy world is worrying about a trivial problem with cell phone radiation. The benefits outweigh the trivial risks, and the WHO branch has failed to investigate the benefits while placing the emphasis solely on cancer risk.
Its good that kids text.

The Bioiniative Report (2007) posits that the reason scientists disagree is that different scientists have different stds. of sufficient evidence. That report recommended higher standards Re: cellphone radiation (i.e., lower emissions). Adopt a public health perspective and think about this, if long term use will eventually be proven harmful, health costs will increase, individual, family and social trauma will result. Better something is proven harmless before it is consumed. That should be a guiding principle when it comes to any new thing we know very little about. But no, the marketplace, in a country where the culture rests on making $, will have the final say, just like with leaded gas and cigarettes.
Have cellphones really made our lives better? Now there is an area where you will clearly find no evidence proving they are harmless!

No one has mentioned the fact that many people - especially young adults - use only cell phones and no longer have land lines. So, it will just be a matter of time before we all find out how much of an affect this has on our health.

Also, I agree with the commenters who wonder about the safety of keeping the cell phone in one's pocket - perhaps there will be fertility/cancer issues for both men and women as a result. I'm picturing people with hands free wires or bluetooth devices in order to 'protect' their brains and meanwhile the phones are in their pockets doing other damage.

With this kind of articles (and most comments attached), USA shows that there is people committed to lucidity. It's unfortunate though that this information is not getting to the public who stay still tuned to Fox News kind of narrative.

#19-
We'll never know, but I bet you the exact same symptoms would have occured if you'd been carrying a block of wood in your pocket the same size as your cellphone.
See for instance "wallet sciatica".
Cell phone use will not be affected by this study. Even were it to be proven correct and reliably true.
Wouldn't it be loverly to see some numbers!

There is a risk of not having a cell phone that likely outweighs the risk of having one. I for one had a car accident and was hanging upsidedown in my car in the woods, unable to get free. I called for help. Anybody hear of a person who was found dad after a snowstorm or landslide and "didn't have a cell phone" to call for help? Most everything has a risk benefit ratio and since my life has already been saved by a cell phone...
